Activity

With a partner, discuss the following situations and their equations. When talking about each equation, you will need to discuss what the solution means in the context of the situation and if certain values are in fact solutions.

Remember, if equations are equivalent and operations are applied correctly to both sides, the solution remains the same in all equivalent equations. If the operations are not applied to both sides properly, the solution will change.

1. Noah is buying a pair of jeans and using a coupon for 10% off. The total price is $56.70, which includes $2.70 in sales tax. Noah’s purchase can be modeled by the equation:

\( x - 0.1x + 2.70 = 56.70 \)

Discuss with a partner:

a. What does the solution to the equation mean in this situation?
b. How can you verify that 70 is not a solution but 60 is the solution?

Enter your answers to questions 1a and 1b here:

a. The solution is the price of a pair of jeans.

b. 70 can be substituted into the equation to make a false statement: 
\( 70-0.1(70) + 2.70 = 56.70 \)
\( 65.70 = 56.70 \) False

60 can be substituted into the equation to make a true statement: 
\( 60-0.1(60) + 2.70 = 56.70 \)
\( 56.70 = 56.70 \) True


2. Here are some equations that are related to \( x - 0.1x + 2.70 = 56.70 \). Each equation is a result of performing one or more moves on that original equation. Each can also be interpreted in terms of Noah’s purchase.

Equation A

\( 100𝑥−10𝑥+270=5,670 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation A here:


Every term was multiplied by 100. The equation is equivalent to Noah’s equation. The price is now expressed in cents instead of dollars. 60 is a solution.


Equation B

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=54 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation B here:

Subtract 2.70 from both sides of the equation. The answer is still in dollars. 60 is a solution.


Equation C

\( 0.9𝑥+2.70=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation C here:

\( x \) and \( 0.1x \) were correctly combined to create an equivalent equation to Noah’s original equation. 10% off means paying 90% of the original price. 90% of the original price plus sales tax is $56.70. 60 is still a solution.


Video: Looking at Equivalent Equations

Watch the following video to learn more about why these are equivalent equations.



3. Here are some other equations. For each equation, determine what move was made or how the equation could be interpreted. Then, check if 60 is the solution to the equation.

Equation D

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation D here:

Sales tax was not included on the left but was included on the right. This equation is not equivalent to Noah’s original equation. The price after using the coupon for 10% off before sales tax is not the same as the price after using the coupon for 10% off including the sales tax, $56.70. 60 is not a solution.


Equation E

\( 𝑥−0.1𝑥=59.40 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation E here:

Subtract 2.70 from the left and add 2.70 to the right. The same operation must be done to both sides of an equation to keep it balanced and to create an equivalent equation. The price after using the coupon for 10% off is not equal to 56.70 plus tax. 60 is not a solution.


Equation F

\( 2(𝑥−0.1𝑥+2.70)=56.70 \)

  • What was done?
  • Interpretation?
  • Same solution?

Enter your answers to equation F here:

The left side was multiplied by 2. Two pairs of jeans after the 10% discount and sales tax cost 56.70. 60 is not a solution.


4. Which of the six equations are equivalent to the original equation? Be prepared to explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Equations A, B, C are equivalent to the original. Interpreting equations can help you understand the cost of items you buy!
